newsitem.title: UK: Amstrad chief says sale to maximise value.
newsitem.headline: Amstrad chief says sale to maximise value.

text.p: Chairman of British consumer electronics firm Amstrad Plc, Alan Sugar, on Tuesday justified the sale of the company's mobile phone business, Dancall Telecom A/S, saying it would maximise shareholder value and would be good for its employees.

In a statement, Sugar said he still appreciated Amstrad's investment in Dancall but regretted that its potential was never understood by financial institutions as it had never made a profit since the acquisition.
"Amstrad felt that it had taken Dancall as far as it could..." Sugar said.
Amstrad said earlier it was selling its Danish unit for 92 million pounds ($150.2 million) to Bosch Telecom GmbH, a unit of Robert Bosch GmbH.
Dancall, with more than 600 employees, manufactures digital mobile telephones for use with GSM and PCN networks.

Investors welcomed the sale after Amstrad said it was considering returning some value out of it to shareholders. Its share price rose to a high of 226 pence from last week's close of 200 and was quoted at 223 pence at 1000 GMT.

Dancall Telecom was previously called Dancall Radio A/S until it ran into financial problems in the late 1980s. Amstrad acquired its assets, mainly the inventory and goodwill, from its receivers in September 1993 through a new company Dancall Telecom for 6.3 million stg.
Last month Sugar told a news conference that Dancall was expected to show profits for 1996/97.
Dancall recently launched two new mobile phones, the Dancall Roamer and the Dancall World phone, both considered technologically superior to those of its competitors in the industry.
Amstrad became a darling for investors in the late 1980s when it was riding on the success of its personal computers, word processors and hi-fi products.
But the group soon began losing market share to bigger Japanese and U.S. competitors.
"Quite correctly, we were determined not to let this happen in the case of Dancall," Sugar said.

"...We decided the best route would be to dispose of the company to a major international organisation that had a depth of technical support and worldwide distribution, and be realistically far better qualified to take the company forward," he added.
